child.pub-comments: “That Proto-Malayo-Polynesian shares the *pitu, *walu, and *Siwa innovations with other *Walu-Siwaic languages...indicated that Proto-Malayo-Polynesian is not a primary branch of Proto-Austronesian, but part of Walu-Siwaic, a branch of Pituic. This is in agreement with Harvey (1979, 1982), Reid (1982), Starosta (1985, 1994, 1995, 1996, 2001), Ross (1995), Benedict (1995), Bellwood (1997), Ho (1998), Ho and Yang (1999), and Sagart (2002)” (Sagart 2004:422).
child.publications: Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.

child.pub-comments: “Note 20: I introduce the acronym FAMP to distinguish the premigration language from PMP [Proto-Malayo-Polynesian] proper, which I believe was spoken in the Philippines” (Sagart 2004:430).
child.publications: Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.
Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.
child.geography: Spoken in parts of south China (Guangxi, Guangdong, and Guizhou provinces), Vietnam, Laos, Thailand, Burma, and Assam.

child.pub-comments: “Note 19: In Sagart (2001; in press, a), FATK [Formosan Ancestor of Tai-Kadai] was called 'AAK' [Austronesian Ancestor of Kadai]. I will from now on use the synonymous but more specific term, FATK” (Sagart 2004:430).
child.publications: Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.
Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.

Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.

child.pub-comments: “Likewise, Northeast Formosan, a taxon consisting of Kavalan and Ketagalan, is accepted on the basis of the documentation in Blust (1999b)” (Sagart 2004:422).
child.publications: Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.

child.pub-comments: “Muic” is a subtaxon of Walu-Siwaic, based on two shared innovations *-mu, 2nd singular genitive, and *manuk “bird” (Sagart 2004:424). According to Sagart, these innovations argue for the existence for Muish, which is ancestral to Kavalan, Ketagalan, and Malayo-Polynesian (2004:425).
child.publications: Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.
Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.

Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.

child.pub-comments: “I need to state that I accept Tsuchida's proposal that Rukai and the three Tsouic languages (Tsou, Kanakanabu, Saaroa) subgroup together on the basis of his documentation” (Sagart 2004:422). See Tsuchida 1976.
child.publications: Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.
Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.

Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.

child.pub-comments: “In another of its [Pituish's] descendants, however watlu had become walu, and it and Siwa eliminated their multiplicative and subtractive competitors, thereby becoming the only words for '8' and '9'. I call the language where this occurred 'Walu-Siwaish.' I regard this language as ancestral to all Austronesian languages except Pazeh, Saisiat, Luilang, Atayalic, Favorlang, Thao, Taokas, Siraya, and Papora and Hoanya as well” (Sagart 2004:422).
child.publications: Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.
Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.
Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.

child.pub-comments: “All other Formosan language, including Siraya, together with all east coast languages and Proto-Malayo-Polynesian, shows reflexes of *enem. In our phylogeny this translates as an innovation from an unknown source, taking place in a language ('Enemish') ancestral to Siraya and Walu-Siwaish. […] However...another lexical innovation supports an Enemish node, and I shall here tentatively accept the Enemish node story” (Sagart 2004:424).
child.publications: Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.
Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.
Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.

child.pub-comments: “Atayalic, a taxon consisting of Atayal and Sediq, is self-evident and has been silently accented in figure 1” (Sagart 2004:422).
child.publications: Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.

child.pub-comments: “I call 'Pituish' the hypothetical daughter language of Proto-Austronesian in which *pitu was first innovated and, having no multiplicative or subtractive competitiors, became the sole word for 'seven.' […] Pituish is ancestral to all Austronesian languages except Pazeh, Saisiat, and Luilang” (Sagart 2004:422).
child.publications: Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.

Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.

root.pub-comments: “The three innovations discussed...have qualities that make them ideal subgrouping criteria. […] I will therefore use the *pitu, *walu, and *Siwa innovations as the backbone of a new, higher Austronesian phylogeny” (Sagart 2004:421).
root.publications: Sagart, Laurent. 2004. The Higher Phylogeny of Austronesian and the Position of Tai-Kadai, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 2 edn., vol. 43, 411-444.
